Project  II  continues  the  government’s  rehabilitation  program  for  the 
conflict-affected  areas  of  the  Northern  and  Eastern  provinces.  Post-
conflict  rehabilitation  will  address  basic  needs  in  the  conflict-affected

In  May  2009,  the  government  defeated  the  Liberation  Tigers  of  Tamil 
Eelam  and  gained  full  control  of  the  Northern  province.  However,  the 
conflict  displaced  more  than  290,000  people  from  districts  in  the 
Northern province. These internally displaced persons (IDPs), who were 
housed in 32 special welfare centers, were in addition to the more than 
150,000  people  who  were  displaced  before  the  renewed  outbreak  of

the  recent  IDPs  living  in  welfare  centers  have  been  relocated  to  their 
original places of residence, or with host families (including friends and 
relatives)  by  the  end  of  January  2010.  The  rest  are  expected  to  be 
resettled by about mid-2010 as demining progresses.

The project will help to meet the urgent basic needs of about 1.5 million 
people,  including  a  significant  number  of  physically  disabled  people, 
households  headed  by  women,  and  children.  By  restoring  sectors  that 
form the backbone of the economy in affected areas, the subprojects will 
help to rebuild communities and stabilize the economic base of the local 
populations,  helping  them  to  move  from  dependence  on  government 
support toward sustainable livelihoods.  
 
The  design  of  NECORD  II  incorporates  safeguards  to  improve  and 
strengthen  governance  and  the  institutional  capacity  of  the  executing 
agencies,  the  implementing  agencies,  and  the  project  management 
units.  
 
Mines and unexploded ordinance are the main risks in the project areas. 
The  government  is  coordinating  with  demining  agencies  to  ensure  that 
the  areas  where  people  are  resettling,  including  subproject  sites,  are 
prioritized. District secretaries are responsible for coordinating demining 
at  the  ground  level,  and  the  executing  agency  is  responsible  at  the 
national level. 
 
Price  escalation  is  another  risk.  An  increase  in  the  demand  for 
construction materials, which are already in short supply, could drive up 
prices and affect the amount of reconstruction that can be carried out in 
the  area.  Based  on  the  lessons  after  the  tsunami,  ADB  has  raised  the 
issue  with  the  government.  Studies  are  under  way  to  identify  adequate 
sites  for  supply  of  construction  materials  and  to  obtain  all  necessary 
statutory permits to facilitate the construction industry.

2. 
Approved  on  14  April  2005,  NECORD  II  was  designed  to  assist  the  Government  of  Sri 
Lanka  with  its  rehabilitation  program  for  the  conflict-affected  areas  of  the  Northern  and  Eastern 
provinces.  The  project  was  processed  concurrently  with  the  Tsunami-Affected  Areas  Rebuilding 
Project2 to ensure that people affected by both the conflict and the December 2004 tsunami would 
benefit  equally  since  they  are  in  the  same  districts.  Post-conflict  rehabilitation  seeks  to  address 
basic  needs  in  the  conflict-affected  areas  through  health,  education,  irrigation,  agriculture, 
community development, institutional infrastructure, and income-generation subprojects. 
 
B. 
 
3. 
The  main  objective  of  NECORD  II  is  to  help meet  basic  human  needs  and  improve  living 
conditions  rapidly  in  conflict-affected  areas  of  the  Northern  and  Eastern  provinces  by  restoring 
basic  social  infrastructure,  community  and  public  services,  and  livelihoods.  NECORD  II  is  also 
supporting  rehabilitation  and  relief  efforts  under  way  in  conflict-affected  areas.  Rehabilitation 
subprojects  under  NECORD  II  will  further  community  development,  rehabilitate  access  roads, 
develop  institutional  infrastructure,  and  restore  basic  infrastructure.  Given  the  recent  increase  in 
construction activity in the Northern and Eastern provinces, an HIV/AIDS awareness campaign will 
be carried out for construction workers and internally displaced persons (IDPs). The project design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

7. 
In May 2009, the government defeated the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam and gained full 
control of the Northern province.3 By the end of the war, about 290,000 IDPs from districts in the 
Northern province were housed in 32 special welfare centers in Jaffna, Mannar, and Vavuniya. An 
additional 150,000 IDPs who had been displaced before the outbreak of the 2006 conflict are still 
living with friends and relatives and in welfare centers in Jaffna, Mannar, Puttalam, and Vavuniya 
districts.  
 
On 1 July 2009, the government launched a 180-day plan4 for emergency rehabilitation and 
8.

and  services  to  facilitate  resettlement  of  IDPs  and  restart  their  livelihoods. By  mid-January  2010,

had returned to their original places of residence or temporary transit centers closer to their original 
places  of  residence,  or  were  staying  with  host  families  (including  friends  and  relatives).5 This  is 
broadly  in  line  with  the  government  target  to  resettle  a  majority  of  these  people  in  their  original

about 100,000 IDPs remain in the main welfare centers, they have been able to move in and out of 
the centers for extended periods since 1 December 2009. These remaining IDPs are expected to 
be resettled in the first half of 2010, after land mines have been cleared.

Review  missions in 2009 observed that some of the infrastructure built or rehabilitated by 
the  government  and  its  development  partners  since  2001  has  been  partially  damaged.  In  most 
cases, the assets have not been destroyed and can be repaired quickly. Interdepartmental teams 
from  the  central  and  provincial  governments  conducted  needs  assessments  for  the  180-day 
program,  as  well  as  the  medium-term  (3  years)  rehabilitation  and  development  of  the  former 
conflict-affected  areas,  in  the  second  quarter  of  2009.  The  180-day  program  is  concentrating 
mainly  on  repairing  the  most  urgently  needed  and  partially  damaged  community  infrastructure, 
while the medium-term program will focus on rebuilding the destroyed larger infrastructure needed 
to support medium- to longer-term development and livelihood needs. Appendix 4 summarizes the 
medium-term  requirement  based  on  the  needs  assessment.  An  estimated  $2,680  million  is 
required  to  meet  the  medium-term  requirements.  The  main  sectors  that  require  support  include 
housing  (more  than  $317  million);  power  ($152  million);  roads  ($949 million);  transport  ($238

11. 
As of 31 December 2009, $25.88 million (99.95%) of the original ADF loan component had 
been committed. The ADF grant and the Sida grant had been fully committed. The disbursements 
were  as  follows:  $22.47  million  (86.77%)  for  the  ADF  loan,  $13.06  million  (93.3%)  for  the  ADF 
grant,  and  $4.77  million  (82.2%)  for  the  Sida  grant.  Of  the  593  subprojects  identified,  more  than 
500 subprojects were completed and handed over to the beneficiaries. The rest of the subprojects 
are progressing satisfactorily and will be completed by March 2010 (the current loan closing date).  
 
12.

covenant includes filling vacancies, especially in the education and health sectors where NECORD 
II  had  the  most  subprojects.  Based  on  the  observations  during  recent  ADB  review  missions,

NECORD II will address the urgent needs of about 1.5 million people, including a significant

resettled  in  their  original  places  of  residence.  By  restoring  essential  community  and  social 
infrastructure and services, as well as agriculture and fisheries sectors that form the backbone of 
the  economy  in  the  affected  areas,  NECORD  II  will  help  to  rebuild  affected  communities  and  to 
stabilize  the  economic  base  of  local  populations,  helping  people  to  move  from  dependence  on 
government support to sustainable livelihoods.

villages in Northern province. 2

A. Links to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
Based  on  the  country  poverty  assessment,  the  country  partnership  strategy,  and  the  sector  analysis,  describes  how  the 
project would directly or indirectly contribute to poverty reduction and how it is linked to the poverty reduction strategy of the 
partner country. 
 
Sri  Lanka's  poverty  reduction  strategy  is  included  in  the  10-year  development  framework  (10YDF)  2006–2016,  Mahinda 
Chintana. ADB's country partnership strategy (CPS) 2009–2011 for Sri Lanka, approved in 2008, is aligned to the framework 
and the program for the next 3 years is focused on the government's priority areas. ADB’s strategy focuses on the two pillars 
identified  in  the  framework.  These  are  (i)  strengthening  the  investment  climate,  and  (ii)  achieving  socially  inclusive 
development.  The  first  pillar  deals  with  infrastructure  development  and  human  resource  development  to  improve 
competitiveness.  The  second  pillar  focuses  on  regional  disparities  and  looks  at  development  of  infrastructure  and 
administrative and absorptive capacity in the poorer regions to improve the delivery of public services.    
 
Comprehensive  poverty  data  is  not  available  for  Northern  and  Eastern  provinces.  However,  poverty  in  the  former  conflict 
areas  is  significant,  with  government  figures  indicating  the  poverty  incidence  at  around  37%,  well  over  twice  the  national 
average  but  still  likely  to  be  an  underestimate.  Destruction  of  assets  and  infrastructure,  displacement,  loss  of  life  and 
livelihood, and destruction of the social fabric characterize the poverty situation in these areas, setting it apart from rest of the 
country. The 10-year development framework has a separate chapter on the conflict-affected areas and states that the current 
policies are designed to protect and resettle displaced communities and to reconstruct the economic and physical and social 
infrastructure with the aim of assuring sustained long-term development of Northern and Eastern provinces. With the ending 
of military operations in May 2009, reconstruction and development of the former conflict areas has become a priority for the 
government. In May 2009 the government formulated a development plan for Northern province, similar to the one developed 
for Eastern provinces as the government gained full control of that province. This is a 3-year plan, which looks at the same 
issues discussed in the Mahinda Chintana. 
  
Through  this  proposed  supplementary  loan  to  NECORD  II,  ADB  will  support  the  government's  efforts  to  meet  basic  human 
needs, particularly of the returning IDPs, and assist them in restarting their livelihood activities through the reconstruction of 
essential community and social infrastructure damaged by the conflict. The emphasis will be on helping to reestablish the civil 
administration,  basic  health  care  and  education  services  as  well  as  support  for  rural  electrification  schemes,  minor  access 
roads, minor irrigation, community water supply, and vocational and skills training for livelihood development. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                                  Targeting Classification: Poverty Intervention 
 
Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Sri Lanka: 
The civil conflict over 3 decades has severely affected the communities in these areas. Loss of life, livelihoods, incomes, and 
property  has  resulted  in  significant  socioeconomic  and  psychological  stress.  In  the  conflict-affected  areas,  essential 
investments have not been made for a long time. 
 
The project will meet basic human needs by reestablishing vital services such as fisheries and irrigation infrastructure, health 
and  educational  facilities,  water  supply,  agricultural  support  services,  and  institutions  to  revive  economic  activities.  This  will 
lead to employment, income generation, rehabilitation of displaced persons, and restoration of social stability in these areas.  
 
Improvement of services and infrastructure will also encourage people to return to their original villages and settlements. With 
this  end  in  view,  the  project  will  strengthen  health  and  educational  facilities,  while  bolstering  local  institutions.  Community-
based  organizations  will  be  established  and  supported,  saving  will  be  encouraged,  women  will  be  made  more  self-reliant, 
microcredit will be introduced, and recreational facilities will be provided.  
                               
In  Northern  and  Eastern  provinces,  the  people  affected  by  the  conflict  are  especially  vulnerable  because  of  gender,  age, 
disability,  and  general  breakdown  in  their  traditional  livelihood  systems.  Internally  displaced  persons  who  wish  to  return  to 
their  areas  of  origin  need  support  in  reestablishing  their  homes  and  their  livelihoods.  Essential  services  such  as  schools, 
hospitals, clinics, water, and power supply are lacking in these areas. The neglect of minor irrigation schemes has constrained 
agricultural  production.  Onetime  surplus  food  production  areas  have  become  food-deficit  areas.  Livestock  numbers  have

II. 

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
The beneficiaries of the project are a war-affected population that had suffered loss of family members, displacement, loss of 
property, lack of access to essential social services, and long years of violence and insecurity. Income levels and human 
development indicators for these areas are among the gravest in Sri Lanka. The conflict and lack of security were the principal 
cause for poverty and the most binding constraint to poverty reduction and economic development. Poverty in these areas is 
due to war-related destruction of property and life, which has set back these regions from where they were prior to the war, 
and lack of development over the last 30 years. Restrictions on movement of people and taking over of property by parties to 
the war have interrupted traditional livelihoods including in agriculture and fisheries. The needs of these communities are 
manifold. It consists of rebuilding and restoration of infrastructure and systems, establishing community life in certain areas, 
provision of basic social services, and connecting these regions with the rest of the country.
